title-group.article-title: Use of full-field measurements to evaluate analytical models for laminates with intralaminar cracks

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratoire d'Energétique et de Mécanique Théorique et Appliquée, Vandœuvre Lès Nancy Cedex, France
2Division of Polymer Engineering, Luleå University of Technology, SE Luleå, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Zoubir Ayadi, Institut Jean Lamour, SI2M, EEIGM 6 Rue Bastien Lepage, F-54010 Nancy Cedex, France Email: zoubir.ayadi@eeigm.inpl-nancy.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Full-field displacement measurements between intralaminar cracks in cross-ply laminates were performed to evaluate the accuracy of shear lag models and Hashin’s model. The dependence of the average crack opening displacement on the crack density was measured and compared with model predictions. It was found that Hashin’s model overestimates the average COD by at least 25%. The value of the shear lag parameter was back-calculated by fitting. With the same goal the strain in the middle between two cracks was measured rendering shear lag parameter which was only 1% different. The found value does not agree with any of the used shear lag models. Measurement shows nonzero intralaminar shear zones in both layers covering a part of the ply thickness.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Intralaminar cracking is the initial damage mode in off-axis plies of laminates subjected to thermo-mechanical loading. Often, these cracks grow nearly instantaneously along the fibers, covering thereby the whole damaged ply (see Figure 1 for a cross-ply laminate). Two fundamentally different approaches are used to describe the degradation of the thermo-elastic properties of a damaged laminate. One approach is based on Continuum Damage Mechanics.1 The second is called ‘micromechanics modeling’ where ‘micro’ prefix means that stress analysis is performed on the level of the elementary damage entities. In the case of damaged laminate, it consists of determining the stress field between intralaminar cracks. Knowing the distribution of cracks, it is then possible to determine the stiffness of the damaged laminate. Besides, the stress distribution is necessary for fracture mechanics modeling: to study the dependence of the crack density on the applied load, see for example Nairn et al.2 Many micromechanics models have been developed and are used to describe the mechanical behavior of damaged laminates.3 Unfortunately, most of the existing analytical micromechanics models are applicable for cross-ply type of laminates only. Calculation schemes for using these stress models to obtain entire stiffness matrix of general symmetric damaged laminates have been suggested in Lundmark and Varna4 and Kashtalyan and Soutis.5 Figure 1.
Transverse cracks in the central ply of a cross-ply laminate.

The simplest and one of the most commonly used micromechanics model is shear lag model, which exists in many modifications. Even if all stress components are accounted for, in axial loading case it is still a one-dimensional model: independent of the used modification it leads to second-order differential equation with constant coefficients to determine the axial stress distribution. Hence, the stress distribution is a superposition of two exponents dependent on the ‘shear lag parameter’. The value of this parameter depends on the used modification of the model and is calculated using assumption regarding the intralaminar shear stress or axial displacement dependence on thickness coordinate. In one of the early version of the shear lag model for damaged laminates,6,7 a resin-rich layer at the 0/90 interface was treated as the layer in which all shear deformation takes place. The problem with this model is that this resin layer has unknown thickness and its existence in high fiber content composites is often questioned. To improve agreement with stiffness measurements, modifications have been introduced where the intralaminar shear region covers the 90-layer8 and also the whole constraint layer.5,9 These models are mechanically inconsistent because the equilibrium equations are satisfied only in an integral sense and shear stress boundary conditions on crack surface are not satisfied at all. Therefore, the shear lag model is often applied using the shear lag parameter from fitting test data or finite element method (FEM) solutions. In models Kashtalyan and Soutis,10 Zhang et al.,11 and Kashtalyan and Soutis,12 the authors summarize FEM results and assume that the intralaminar shear stress has linear z-distribution only in a part of the constraint layer (0-layer in cross-ply laminate) and equals to zero in the rest of the constraint layer. The thickness of this ‘part’ becomes a fitting parameter. In predictions authors consistently use it equal to the thickness of one prepreg layer. Authors themselves have mentioned that it is conceptually incorrect because the thickness of this zone should rather be proportional to the crack size (90-layer thickness) than to the thickness of the prepreg tape.

A model which is free of these theoretical inconsistencies and uncertainties was developed by Hashin.13 The hypothesis of his model, that the intralaminar shear stress has a linear distribution across thickness, has never been verified experimentally. Refined variational model was developed in Varna and Berglund14 with exponential intralaminar shear stress distribution obtained as the result of solution.

So, the shortcomings of these models are well known but we appreciate the simplicity of their application. Validation of an analytical micromechanics model consists of two parts: (a) the adequacy of the physical model to real crack (including crack geometry); (b) the numerical accuracy of the mathematical solution applied for this model. The latter can be verified comparing the obtained stress distributions with stress state obtained using FEM, see Krasnikovs and Varna15 for example. The adequacy of a model with accurate mathematical solution can be validated on the macroscopic scale by comparing the measured values of the elastic constants of a damaged laminate and the predicted values for example as in Hashin,13 Varna and Berglund,14 and Joffe et al.16 In Laws and Dvorak17 the measured stiffness reduction was used to back-calculate the shear lag parameter. Unfortunately, errors of a ‘slightly inadequate’ crack model with ‘slightly approximate’ mathematical solution may compensate leading to good predictions, for example, when Hashin’s model (lower bound) is applied to predict elastic modulus of laminate with small local delaminations not included in the model. Therefore, verifying models with measured local strain parameters is of primary importance. Raman spectroscopy was used in Katerelos et al.18 to obtain the nonuniform local strain distribution in the constraint layer caused by cracks in the neighboring layer. Unfortunately, the Raman strain measurements in the sensor fiber located close to the interface were used only to find the number of cracks in the ‘Raman window’ and to find the macroscopic strain applied to this ‘window’. In other words the experimental result from these measurements was only macroscopic elastic modulus reduction with crack density which could be obtained also by different tools. The local strain distribution was not used to validate the used models.

The objective of this article is to evaluate the suitability of the models discussed above with respect to the local displacement field parameters measured in the region between cracks using Electronic Speckle Pattern Interferometry (ESPI) for the given CF/EP [02/903]S laminate.

Consequently, we present an experimental evaluation of the shear lag and variational models (Hashin’s model and Model 2 in Varna and Berglund14) at the crack scale. This objective naturally leads to envisage the use of a full-field measurement technique. In the present work, we have measured the displacement field on the edge of a cracked cross-ply carbon epoxy laminate by using ESPI.19 Thereafter, experimental displacement fields have been used to evaluate the range of validity of the shear lag models and of the variational models. The following characteristics of the stress–strain state obtained experimentally and from models will be compared:
ratio of through the thickness averaged axial strain in the 0° ply and in the 90° ply in the middle between two cracks
the crack opening displacement values of cracks

sec.title: Stress, strain, and displacement fields in a cracked laminate
Stress–strain state between two cracks
sec.p: For the sake of conciseness, we will only consider the case that was experimentally studied in this work: a cross-ply laminate with cracks in the central ply (Figure 1). Nevertheless, the generalization to [S,90m]s configurations (S: orthotropic sublaminate) is straightforward.20

The laminate is subjected to a tensile load along the x-axis. In a region between two crack (Figure 2), the stress in the damaged 90∘ ply is reduced and can be described by means of the following equation: (1)σx90(x,z)=σx090(1-f(x,z,l)) Figure 2.
Elementary damage cell (1 pixel represents 18.26 µm).

σx090 is the stress in the 90∘ ply for an undamaged laminate that would be subjected to the same average stress: σxLAM; l is the half length of the damage cell; f(x,z,l) represents stress perturbation caused by cracks. The average of a function over ply thickness (‘thickness average’) is denoted with upper bar: (2)σ¯x90(x)=1(t90/2)∫0t90/2σx90(x,z)dz andf¯(x,l)=1(t90/2)∫0t90/2f(x,z,l)dz leading to (3)σ¯x90(x)=σx090(1-f¯(x,l))
From the force balance at arbitrary x we obtain thickness averaged stress in 0° ply: (4)σ¯x0=σx00+σx090t902t0f¯(x,l)
Thickness averaged strains are introduced in the same way as in Equation (2).

The ratio between the thickness average strains in the 0° ply and in the 90° ply, taken in the middle between the cracks: ɛ¯x0(x=0)/ɛ¯x90(x=0), will be obtained in this paper experimentally. Our measurements will be compared with shear lag models and Hashin’s model. Since these models are based on plane stress formulation, σy0=0: all in-plane Poisson’s effects are ignored. Assuming that far from the cracks σz can be neglected (this assumption can be verified by finite element method modeling) and using Hook’s law we obtain: (5)ɛ¯x0(x)=σ¯x0(x)E1and ɛ¯x90(x)=σ¯x90(x)E2
With Equations (3)–(5) and the isostrain hypothesis for an undamaged laminate, one can write: (6)ɛ¯x0(0)ɛ¯x90(0)=1+E2E1t90/2t0f¯(0)1-f¯(0)

sec.title: Expression for COD
sec.p:
Assumptions regarding the stress–strain state used in this section are the same as in shear lag and Hashin’s models to be evaluated. Due to assumed symmetry at x=l, u0(l) does not depend on the z coordinate. The relative displacement of a point on surface of a crack located at x=l (Figure 3) is given by: (7)u0(l)-u90(l,z) The crack opening displacement, COD is two times larger and its average value can be written as: (8)COD¯=2(u0(l)-2t90∫0t90/t9022u90(l,z)dz) Figure 3.
Opening of a crack along the damaged ply thickness.

We introduce volume average of stress and strain related functions as integral over the relevant ply volume divided by this volume. In the models to be validated, the stress-strain state does not depend on the y coordinate. Therefore, the averaging in a layer is according to expression shown for the stress perturbation function: (9)fa(l)=1(t90/2)l∫0t90/2∫0lf(x,z)dxdz
In the 0° ply u0(l) is given by: (10)u0(l)=∫0lɛx0(x,z)dx=1t0∫0l∫t90/2t90/2+t0ɛx0(x,z)dzdx=lɛxa0
Using similar expression for u90(l,z) and replacing average strain in the layer by stresses according to Hooke’s law we obtain: (11)COD¯=2l(σxa0E1-σxa90E2)
Deriving Equation (11), we used plane stress assumption σya90=σya0=0 and the fact that the average stress in z-direction is zero.

Finally, relationships (3) and (4) are valid also for volume averaged quantities. Substituting the corresponding relationships in (12) and using the isostrain hypothesis for an undamaged laminate (i.e. σx00/E1=σx090/E2=σxLAM/Ex0LAM with Ex0LAM=(t0E1+(t90/2)E2)/(t90/2+t0) being the longitudinal modulus of an undamaged laminate), we obtain: (12)COD¯=2σxLAMt90/2+t0E1t0lfa(l)

In practice, the cracks may not be uniformly distributed and a given crack is not situated at equal distance from the two neighboring cracks on its left (distance: 2l1) and on its right side (distance: 2l2), respectively. This is illustrated on Figure 4 for the crack denoted Crack_b. We will make the assumption that the average COD in this case can be calculated as an average of two solutions for uniformly spaced cracks: (13)COD¯=0.5(COD¯(l1)+COD¯(l2))leading to:COD¯=σxLAMt90/2+t0E1t0(l1fa(l1)+l2fa(l2)) Figure 4.
Distribution of the cracks in the region of study.

The numerical accuracy of this assumption has been verified by means of finite element modeling in Loukil et al.21 In the section ‘Displacement measurements and shear lag model’ we will use ESPI to compare the calculated average crack opening displacement, COD¯ to the value measured on the midplane, COD(z=0). It can be done by assuming that the crack opening has an elliptical shape. In a previous paper,22 this hypothesis for the considered laminate was experimentally verified. The major axis of the ellipse is t90 (Figure 2). The minor axis of the ellipse is COD(0). The equation of an ellipse writes: (14)(COD(z)COD(0))2+(zt90/2)2=1
With Equation (14), we can relate COD¯ and COD(0): (15)COD¯=π4COD(0)

sec.title: Micromechanics models
sec.p: We will consider two commonly used micromechanics models, each one leading to certain perturbation function (the shear lag model and the variational models) to evaluate the results yielded by Equation (6), and Equations (13) and (15) with the experimental data from ESPI.

sec.title: Shear lag model
sec.p: The shear lag model is basically a one dimensional analysis, applicable to balanced symmetric laminates, containing cracked plies of 90° orientation with respect to the tensile direction.20 This model was first used for damaged laminates by Garrett and Bailey in 1977.6 Many modifications of this model have been developed; however, the perturbation function is always given by expression: (16)f¯ ShL(x)=cosh(βxt90/2)cosh(βlt90/2)
According to (9): (17)faShL(l)=t90/2lβtanh(βlt90/2)

The value of the shear lag parameter β governs the rate of stress transfer from the 90° ply to the 0° ply. The value of the shear lag parameter, β depends on the assumptions made about the shear strain distribution layer:
Hypothesis A: Shear strain in the 0° ply is zero while the displacement in the 90° ply varies linearly in z6,7 In that case: (18)β2=G23H with H=(t0E1+(t90/2)E2)/(t0E1E2).
Hypothesis B: Zero shear strain in the 0° ply whereas the displacement in the 90° ply is parabolic in z8 leading to: (19)β2=3G23H

Hypothesis C: Zero shear strain in 0° and 90° ply. All the shear strain is in a homogeneous layer at 0/90 interface, which thickness and shear modulus are respectively denoted Gm and d.23 In practice, the shear layer is often assumed to be a resin-rich region of very small thickness at the interface between the plies. Gm is then the shear modulus of the matrix. (20)β2=t90/2dGmH

Logically, with Gm=G23 and d=t90/2, the A and the C cases are equivalent. In A and B cases the β values are significantly different, even if the B case can be considered as a refinement of the A case with a more realistic assumption for the displacement in the 90° ply. As previously mentioned, in the C case, the hypothesis about the thickness is very different: this region is assumed to be small compared to the ply thicknesses. Expressions for shear lag parameter for models where the intralaminar shear stress acts over the entire 0-layer or part of it are given in Nuismer and Tan9 and Kashtalyan and Soutis,12 respectively.

sec.title: Variational models
sec.p: In Hashin’s model8 the perturbation function is obtained by minimizing the complementary energy. Contrary to the shear lag model, in the case of the Hashin’s model, the perturbation function depends only on known quantities. Since this model is used here to compare the COD¯ values only, we present only the expression for faHashin14: (21)faHash(l)=t902l2ABA2+B2cosh(2Alt90/2)-cos(2Blt90/2)Bsinh(2Alt90/2)+Asin(2Blt90/2) (22)A=122q-p B=2q-pp=(C2-C4)/C3 q=C1/C3C1=1E2+t90/2t0E1 C4=13G23+t03(t90/2)G13C2=ν23E2(t0t90/2+23)-t0ν123(t90/2)E1C3=160E2(3(t0(t90/2))3+15(t0(t90/2))2+20(t0(t90/2))+8)
This solution is applicable if 4q/p2>1 which is satisfied for typical polymer composite.

These expressions are valid also for the more refined variational Model 2 in Varna and Berglund14 in which the shape of intralaminar shear stress in 0-layer is exponential with shape parameter determined minimizing complementary energy (called 2D-0 model in following).

sec.title: Material
sec.p: The [02,903]s laminate (Figure 2) was made of toughened carbon fiber/epoxy (AS4/8552) unidirectional (UD) tape prepreg using vacuum bag technique. Laminate thickness was 1.28 mm. The elastic properties obtained in tests on UD and angle-ply specimens are: E1=138GPa, E2=10.3GPa, ν12=0.27,ν23=0.40, G12=5.5GPa, G23=4GPa
Cracks were created by subjecting the specimen to 0.71% tensile strain.

sec.title: Experimental technique: ESPI measurement
sec.p: The displacement field along the x direction (tensile direction) on the specimen edge was measured. The well-known Leendertz arrangement24 was used. The characteristics of experimental set-up have been presented elsewhere.22

In order to reduce the measurement noise, it is necessary to smoothen the data: the phase maps were averaged using a [7 pixels × 7 pixels] filtering kernel. The size of the filtering kernel (7 pixels) was specifically chosen in order to allow exactly two independent measurements along the thickness direction in each of the 0° plies and six independent measurements in the central ply (Figure 4) The pixel size being 18.26μm, it approximately corresponds to a 130μm value for the spatial resolution. In other words, it is the size of the region on which the displacement measurement is averaged.

sec.title: Displacement field in the region of study
sec.p:
At a very low load level, the damaged specimen was subjected to a small increment of the applied stress: σxLAM=11.7MPa. Figure 5 shows displacement profiles in the two 0° plies and in the cracked central ply. In the damaged ply, it is possible to detect displacement jumps (shown for Crack_d on Figure 5) corresponding to cracks and therefore to evaluate the crack opening displacement (COD) generated by the increment of the applied stress (see Farge et al.22 for a more details). In the region of study, four cracks are visible. Micromechanics models described in the section ‘Stress, strain, and displacement fields in a cracked laminate’ can be used for three regions corresponding to crack spacing of respectively: 2l=121pixels, 2l=105pixels, and 2l=73pixels (Figure 4). Using shear lag model and experimental data, the value of the shear lag parameter for each of these regions can be found. Figure 5.
Displacement profiles. The displacement jumps correspond to the opening value on the midplane.

It is important to note that, because of the filtering, the displacement profiles shown on Figure 5 are not measured along a straight line, but along a 7 pixels thick strip. In the 0° plies, these strips are located respectively at the upper and at the lower sides of the specimen edge. In the 90° ply, the profile is measured along a strip in the central region of the edge (Figure 4).

Comparing the top and bottom 0° plies in Figure 5, we notice a shift of the displacement profile. Most probably it is due to a very slight parasitic out-of-plane rotation (bending) of the imperfect specimen. Anyway, in the following, all the strain or COD measurements are obtained along the tensile axis. Consequently, the described parasitic rotation has no effect.

sec.title: Displacement measurements and shear lag model
Problems to address
sec.p:
The shear lag parameter β is required to implement the shear lag model. To our knowledge, this parameter has never been determined using field measurements in the vicinity of intralaminar cracks. In this work, we propose to determine β in two different ways:
We will measure the strain in the middle between cracks and we will determine β using Equations (6) and (16).
We will experimentally measure the crack opening and β will be obtained using Equations (13) and (17).

Micromechanics models are often aimed at describing the dependence of the laminate stiffness on the crack density (ρ=1/2l). It is therefore an absolute necessity that the shear lag parameter is independent of the crack spacing. This question is addressed below. Besides, by analyzing the displacement and strain profiles along the thickness direction z, we will discuss the assumptions that are made about the size of the shear region which is the main distinction between different shear lag models.

sec.title: Shear lag parameter determination using the displacement field between cracks
sec.p: In this section, we describe estimation of the shear lag parameter β based on the measured values of axial strain in the middle between two cracks, x=0. According to Equations (6) and (16): (23)coshβ2lt90=ɛ¯x0(0)ɛ¯x90(0)+t90/2t0E2E1ɛ¯x0(0)ɛ¯x90(0)-1

As previously mentioned, ESPI provides displacement distribution and the axial strain ɛx is calculated as the derivative with respect to x. Because of the noise that affects the displacement profiles, the estimation of the displacement slope is performed over the interval [x=-P,x=P] with P=15pixels (Figure 5). One must keep in mind that the displacement measurement has previously been averaged with a 7 pixels square kernel. Consequently, there are two independent strain measurements in each of the 0° plies and six independent strain measurements in the 90° ply.

Figure 6 shows the strain profiles along the specimen thickness. As expected, the strain is larger in the 0° plies than in the 90° one, which is naturally a consequence of the stress transfer between these two plies. Figure 6.
Strain profiles in the middle between the cracks. The horizontal bars correspond to the filtering kernel.

By calculating the mean of the four values in the 0° ply and of the six values in the 90° ply, it is possible to obtain the average strains in each ply (denoted ɛ¯x0(0) and ɛ¯x90(0)) as well as the ratio of these two quantities ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0) (Table 1). As expected, ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0) approach to one with the crack spacing l. Table 1.
Strain measurements and the resulting value for β
Region ɛ¯x0(0) (×104) ɛ¯x90(0) (×104) ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0) l(pixels) β
Region 1 (between Crack_a and Crack_b) 1.64 1.30 1.24 60.5 0.838
Region 2 (between Crack_b and Crack_c) 1.68 1.19 1.41 52.5 0.794
Region 3 (between Crack_c and Crack_d) 1.66 0.87 1.91 36.5 0.827
Finally, the shear lag parameter β can be obtained with Equation (3). The corresponding results are given in the last column of Table 1.

Due to the fact that the displacement slope is calculated over the x∈[-P,+P] interval (P=15Pixels≈0.28mm), the measured strains (denoted in following ɛ¯xP0(0) and ɛ¯xP90(0)) do not correspond exactly to the strain values for x=0 (Figure 5). We assume that the measured values result from an averaging along the x direction over the [-P,+P] interval: (24)ɛ¯xP90(0)=12P∫-PPɛ¯x90(x)dx (25)ɛ¯xP0(0)=12P∫-PPɛ¯x0(x)dx

In the x∈[-P,+P] interval Equation (5) are applicable. With Equations (3), (4), and (16), the integration in Equation (24) and (25) can be performed leading to following expressions: (26)ɛ¯x90(0)=ɛ¯xP90cosh(βlt90/2)-1cosh(βlt90/2)-t90/2βPsinh(βPt90) (27)ɛ¯0(0)=ɛ¯xP0cosh(βlt90/2)+E2E1t90/2t0cosh(βlt90/2)+E2E1(t90/2)2βPt0sinh(βPt90/2)

The previously determined value (last column of Table 1) of the shear lag parameter can be introduced in Equations (26) and (27) to find a corrected value for the ratio ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0). Then Equation (23) can be used again to obtain a corrected value of the shear lag parameter corresponding to the updated value of ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0). This procedure can be reiterated until convergence is reached for β. The results are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Corrected values for the strains and the resulting value for β
Region ɛ¯xP90/ɛ¯x90(0) ɛ¯xP0/ɛ¯x0(0) ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0) (corrected) β (corrected)
Region 1 (between Crack_a and Crack_b) 0.987 1.0012 1.22 0.857
Region 2 (between Crack_b and Crack_c) 0.981 1.0015 1.38 0.818
Region 3 (between Crack_c and Crack_d) 0.952 1.0029 1.81 0.860

In fact, because of the initial averaging of the displacement, a few pixels outside the [-P,P] interval are included in the displacement slope determination. Nevertheless, the weight of these pixels is very small and it can be seen that the results given by Equations (26) and (27) are nearly unchanged.

sec.title: Shear lag parameter determination from COD measurements
sec.p: The purpose of this section is to back-calculate the shear lag parameter from the crack opening displacement measurements. The COD(0) values are indicated on Figure 5 for the four cracks. With Equations (13), (15), and (17) it is easy to obtain an implicit equation for β: (28)β=t90/2σxLAMπ4COD(0)[t90/2+t0t0E1][tanh(βl1t90)+tanh(βl2t90)]

This equation can be solved numerically; for example by means of iterative procedure. Table 3 summarizes results for Crack_b, Crack_c, and Crack_d. Unfortunately, the distance between Crack_a and the closest crack at the left side was not measured and β for Crack_a is not available. The distance between Crack_d and the closest crack at the right side was also not measured. But, for this crack, we know that l2>123/2=61.5pixels(Figure 5). Moreover, it is not possible to observe any significant decrease of the slope of the displacement profile on the midplane in this region. Such a decrease would reveal the close presence of a crack. l2 is therefore significantly larger than 61.5 pixels. With a reasonable value of β (for example β=0.85), we obtain tanh(βl2/t90)>0.986. It is therefore possible to consider that for Crack_d l2→∞, then tanhβl2/t90=1. Table 3.
Crack opening displacement values and the resulting values for β parameter and COD¯COD∞¯
Region l1(pixels) l2(pixels) COD(0)(μm) β COD¯COD∞¯
Crack_b 60.5 52.5 0.231 0.869 98.1%
Crack_c 53.5 36.5 0.224 0.857 93.8%
Crack_d 36.5 ∞ 0.231 0.841 94.8%

Because of the initial filtering of the phase maps, the measured value CODmeasured(0) is not exactly taken on the midplane. It is in fact an averaging along the opening profile over the 7 pixels of the filtering kernel: CODmeasured(0)=27×∫072 pixelsCOD(z)dz It results in a slight underestimation of COD(0). In the case of an elliptical profile along the ply thickness the corresponding bias can be evaluated using Equation (14). It can be shown that the measured value is less than 0.5% smaller than the COD(0). As a consequence, no correction to the measurements was made. Naturally, an averaging of the displacement is also performed over 7 pixels along the x direction. At the crack surfaces, due to the traction free boundary conditions, the displacement remains nearly constant in the x direction over the small region close to the crack surfaces where the measurement is taken (For a more details, see Farge et al.22). Consequently, the error on the COD measurement resulting from the averaging along the x direction can also be neglected. Figure 7.
Displacement profile along the ply thickness.

sec.title: Shear lag parameter
sec.p: The shear lag parameter β was obtained in two different ways. Using the displacement slope (strain) in a small region in the middle between two cracks (Table 2), the mean of the three measurements corresponding to different crack spacings is βmeanstrain=0.848. These three measurements are comprised in a 3.6% interval around this mean value. For the considered laminate, the shear lag parameter that governs the stress transfer seems to be independent of the crack spacing, which is a necessary condition to use the shear lag model to describe the evolution of the laminate stiffness as a function of crack density.

For the three analyzed cracks the COD values on the midplane (COD(0) on Table 3) lead to the mean value βmeanCOD=0.856. The three measurements are comprised in a 1.8% interval around this mean value. Agreement between βmeanstrain and βmeanCOD (difference ≈ 1%) is very good.

These results should not be considered as a proof of validity of any of the shear lag model. They are just confirming that for varying crack spacing the shape of the stress distribution between two cracks can be described by linear combination of two exponents with the same fixed shape parameter.

It is also possible to compare our experimental values for the shear lag parameter with the theoretical expressions obtained by making some assumptions about the variation of the displacement along the specimen thickness (see section ‘Micromechanics models’). With that aim, in Figure 7, we have plotted the u(z) displacement profiles along the specimen thickness. This curve was obtained for x=184pixels, which is situated at 10pixels on the right side of Crack_b. It is important to keep in mind the effect of the 7 pixels filtering kernel, the data is smoothed, which makes it impossible to detect some abrupt variation of the curve, particularly at the ply interfaces. Besides, because of the previously mentioned parasitic rotation, the curve is not perfectly symmetric with respect to the midplane. Anyway, it is still possible to observe that the displacement is z-dependent indicating presence of intralaminar shear strains in a region, which covers an important portion of the central ply thickness and even part of the 0-layer. This observation invalidates Hypothesis C presented in the section ‘Micromechanics models.’ According to Equation (18) corresponding to Hypothesis A, the β value should be 0.66, which is significantly smaller than the measured values. In fact, it is possible to distinguish a region in the midplane vicinity where the displacement is constant. Consequently, the layer in which the displacement varies with z has a thickness d smaller than t90/2. As a consequence, Equation (20) may be applicable with a d value smaller than t90/2 (roughly d=0.6×(t90/2) on Figure 7) and Gm=G23.The shear lag parameter should then be larger than the value calculated using Equation (18), which is in agreement with our observations. Besides, using Equation (19) (Hypothesis B), we obtain β=1.14.

It should be noted that the displacement is not constant in the vicinity of the ply interfaces in the 0° plies. It is particularly visible for the right 0° ply in Figure 7. Even if this may be partly a consequence of the filtering, shear strains are expected also in a part of the 0-ply as it has been included in the shear lag model modification11,12 assuming linear shear stress in one prepreg ply of the 0-layer. Nevertheless, the shear lag parameter according to Kashtalyan and Soutis,12 β=0.997 is rather different than the experimental βmeanCOD=0.856. The shear lag model9 assuming linear intralaminar shear stress over the entire 0-layer renders β=0.934, which is closer to the experimental value.

sec.title: Hashin’s model
sec.p:
By inserting Equation (21) in Equation (13) the COD¯ values yielded by the Hashin’s model can be calculated. With the assumption of an elliptical opening, the value on the midplane, CODHashin(0) is given by Equation (15). For Crack_b, Crack_c, Crack_d, the values for CODHashin(0) are shown in Table 4. The values for the crack openings obtained using Hashin’s model are roughly 25% higher than the ESPI values given in Table 3. Values calculated by the 2D-0 model14 in Table 4 are lower and closer to experimental data still overestimating the crack opening displacement. This model was used also to calculate ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0) between cracks a-b, b-c, and c-d. The values 1.082, 1.188, and 1.932 are close to the experimental in Table 2. The values according to Hashin’s model are 1.18, 1.37, and 2.62. Table 4.
Crack Opening Displacement predictions (COD(0)) corresponding to three different approaches
Region Hashin’s 2D-0 Power law4
model Model14
Region 1 (between Crack_a and Crack_b) 0.294 0.255 0.216
Region 2 (between Crack_b and Crack_c) 0.286 0.253 0.212
Region 3 (between Crack_c and Crack_d) 0.285 0.253 0.213

The 2D-0 model predicts that in the 0-layer at a distance from interface equal to 15% of the 90-layer thickness the intralaminar shear stress is five times lower than at the interface, which is in a good qualitative agreement with Figure 7.

The ‘power law’ which was introduced in Lundmark and Varna4 as a fitting to FEM results gives slightly lower values of the crack opening than the experimental. Calculations using McCartney26 are expected to give numerically coinciding results with FEM. Explanation for measured values higher than FEM could be in small local delamination at transverse crack tip. They were not observed by optical microscopy, but their presence would increase the COD and lead to increased stiffness reduction as predicted by model presented in Lundmark and Varna.4 Another possible reason for experimental values being higher than FEM could be edge effect: measurements are on the edge where crack face openings could be slightly larger.

sec.title: Crack interactions
sec.p: Substituting Equation (16) for the shear lag model in Equation (3) we can calculate the thickness averaged stress in the middle between two cracks, x=0: (29)σ¯x90(0)σx090=1-1cosh(βlt90/2)
Using Equation (17) for average stress faShL in expression (12) we obtain for average COD. (30)COD¯COD∞¯=tanh(βlt90/2)

In Equation (30) COD¯∞ is for a single crack. By choosing the experimental value of the shear lag parameter, β=0.85 and referring to it as ‘our shear lag model’, we analyze the effects of the crack interaction on the stress between cracks and on the COD¯ values.

On Figure 8, we show the calculated evolution σ¯x90(0)/σx090 and COD¯/COD∞¯. For cracks experimentally studied in this work (36.5pixels<l<60.5pixels), σ¯x90(0)/σx090 is comprised between 56.6% and 82.8% and COD¯/COD∞¯ is comprised between 90.1% and 98.5%. The opening of all cracks that are present in the region of study are thus close to the value corresponding to a perfectly non interacting crack. Using our shear lag model and l/t90/2≥2, we obtain COD¯/COD∞¯≥0.935. Thus the effect of crack interactions on the average opening value is very small but not completely negligible. This result is in good agreement with numerical modeling by Joffe et al.16 using FEM for a [02,904]s carbon epoxy laminates. In the Joffe et al. paper, it was impossible to detect any significant reduction of the COD values for l/t90/2≈2 and the threshold below which the effect of crack interaction can not be neglected was rather l/t90/2=1.5. This difference compared to the present case is due to different material properties in Joffe et al.,16 which according to Equation (18) lead to about 36% larger shear lag parameter, which result in smaller interaction effects. Figure 8.
Effect of crack interaction.

Thus, evaluating the COD values for the experimentally studied cracks the effects of crack interaction can be nearly neglected. For perfectly noninteractive cracks the strain profiles in each ply would exhibit a plateau region with the same constant strain value, just like for an undamaged laminate. Measurements show that ɛ¯x0(0)/ɛ¯x90(0)≠1 (see Table 2, Column 3) and in this sense these cracks can not be considered as non-interactive. Corresponding values according to the used variational models are presented in the section ‘Hashin’s model.’

The COD¯ as a function of l/(t90/2) calculated according to our shear lag model and Hashin’s model is shown in Figure 9. The value of the load level is the one that was experimentally applied to the laminate (σxLAM=11.7MPa). The experimental points are also indicated for Crack_b, Crack_c, and Crack_d. For the experimental points, an equivalent uniform crack spacing leq was defined as follows: 1/leq=1/2(1/l1+1/l2). The agreement between the experimental data and our shear lag model is good. In a previous paper,22 additional loads of higher level were applied to the laminate, resulting in creation of new cracks. In particular, a new crack was created at 60 pixels at the right side of Crack_d. After the creation of this new crack, for Crack_d the leq value was changed:leq/(t90/2)=1.57 that is smaller than the value for which the effect of crack interaction on the COD¯ value starts to be significant. It was experimentally shown that the creation of this new crack causes a small but measurable reduction of the crack opening displacement of about 15% for Crack_d. This value is put as a new experimental point on Figure 9. Even for this new point the agreement with our shear lag model is good. Apparently, the shear lag model, implemented with the value of the shear lag parameter determined by our measurements, allows the description of the crack opening displacement reduction due to the effect of crack interactions. It has to be realized that the discussed results based on the experimental shear lag parameter value in fact are rather self-predictive. Figure 9.
COD¯ against crack spacing (σxLAM=11.7MPa).

In Figure 9, we have also represented the curve indicating the dependence of COD¯ on the crack spacing according to the Hashin’s model. As previously mentioned, the values predicted by the model are about 25% larger compared to the experimental points. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that the threshold at which the cracks start to interact is similar for the two models. Compared to perfectly noninteractive cracks, a 5% reduction of the opening value occurs at l/(t90/2)≈2.15 according to the shear lag model and at l/(t90/2)≈1.75 according to the Hashin’s model. The stress analysis in the 2D-0 model is more accurate and the results are closer to experimental.

Finally, we have to address several questions related to experimental procedures of the ESPI method and possible implications. This technique is used to obtain displacement field on the surface and can be applied on both specimen edges as well as on top and bottom surfaces. In another ongoing study it is used to study cracks in surface layers. Method does not require any special edge treatment which would influence damage development and has certain advantages with respect, for example, Raman spectroscopy. To measure strains between cracks with Raman spectroscopy the sensor fiber has to be broken at crack surface with unknown level of debonding. Actually the fiber would not break at 0.5% strain when the transverse cracking usually starts. Alignment of the sensor fiber along the midplane may also be a problem.

The extent of other damage modes like delaminations and longitudinal splitting can be evaluated by their effect on crack opening and sliding displacements. For example, splitting in 0-layers practically does not affect the crack opening in 90-layer but it affects the crack face sliding. Local delaminations which are often difficult to measure have effect on both of them and the measurements can be used to estimate the delamination length by back-calculation using reliable model.

In off-axis layers the crack face displacement measured on the edge contains the opening and the sliding part. In order to separate them, measurements under two different angles have to be performed on the same crack.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The ESPI displacement measurements were used to evaluate the accuracy of shear lag models and two variational models.

The dependence of the average COD on the crack density was measured and compared with model predictions. It was found that Hashin’s model overestimates the average COD by at least 25% whereas shear lag models can render very different values dependent on the selected shear lag parameter.

Average COD data from ESPI were used to back-calculate by fitting the value of the shear lag parameter. With the same goal the strain in the middle between two cracks was measured rendering alternative shear lag parameter value which was only 1% different.

It was shown that in the considered range the back-calculated shear lag parameter does not depend on the spacing between cracks which makes the expressions with this parameter suitable for stiffness degradation modeling for this particular composite.

It was found that the crack interaction effect on the average COD is much weaker than the effect on the stress in the middle between two cracks which is an indication that modeling stiffness reduction cracks may be often considered as non-interactive, whereas interaction is more important analyzing initiation of new cracks.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: None declared.
